original: Majjhima Nikāya 37
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhayasutta
analyzed: cūḷa taṇhā saṅkhaya sutta
translated: The Shorter Discourse on the Destruction of Craving

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati pubbārāme migāra mātu pāsāde
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in the Eastern Park in the Mansion of Migāra’s Mother.

original: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi ekamantam ṭhitaḥ kho sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then Sakka, the ruler of the gods, approached the Blessed One, paid homage to him, stood to one side, and said to him:

original: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti
translated: “Bhante, in what way is a bhikkhu liberated by the destruction of craving, the one of complete peace and perfect purity, the supreme noble one, the supreme returner, the supreme human, the supreme trainee, the foremost person, the foremost in the world, the foremost young man, the foremost one anointed with the out-of-the-ordinary anointing, the foremost one who has entered the plane of the noble ones, the foremost one who has entered the plane of the noble path, the foremost one who has entered the plane of the noble ones’ right way of practice, the foremost one who has entered the plane of the noble ones’ right way of practice that leads to complete disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna?”

original: “Idha, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti:
analyzed: idha devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: “Here, ruler of the gods, a bhikkhu has heard:

original: ‘sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā’ti.
analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: ‘All phenomena are unworthy of attachment.’

original: Evañcetaṁ, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti:
analyzed: evam ca ita devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: If a bhikkhu has heard this,

original: ‘sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā’ti.
analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: ‘All phenomena are unworthy of attachment,’

original: So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti; sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti; sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti—
analyzed: so sabbam dhammam abhijānāti sabbam dhammam abhiññāya sabbam dhammam parijānāti sabbam dhammam pariññāya yam kiñci vedanam vedeti
translated: He directly knows all things. Having directly known all things, he fully understands all things. Having fully understood all things, whatever feeling he feels,

original: sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, so tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
analyzed: sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā so tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharati virāga anupassī viharati nirodha anupassī viharati paṭinissagga anupassī viharati
translated: whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant, he dwells contemplating impermanence in those feelings, contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings.

original: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto, paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati.
analyzed: so tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharantaḥ virāga anupassī viharantaḥ nirodha anupassī viharantaḥ paṭinissagga anupassī viharantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: As he dwells contemplating impermanence in those feelings, contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings, he does not cling to anything in the world.

original: Anupādiyaṁ na paritassati, aparitassaṁ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:🔽‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: anupādiyam na paritassati a paritassam paccattaññā iva parinibbāyati 🔽brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he does not cling, he is not

original: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.🔽Atha kho sakko devānamindo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.🔽Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho devānaminda bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti  atha kho sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā tattha iva antaradhāyi  tena khalu pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhagavataḥ avidūre nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: To this extent, ruler of the devas, a bhikkhu is liberated by mind, is liberated by wisdom, is one perfected in mind, is an ascetic, an accomplished one, a fully enlightened one, the best of men, the supreme one, the trainer of those to be trained, the teacher of gods and men. ”🔽Then Sakka, ruler of the devas, delighting and rejoicing in the Blessed One’s words, paid homage to the Blessed One, and vanished right there.🔽Now on that occasion the venerable Maha Moggallana was sitting not far from the Blessed One.🔽

original: Atha kho āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa etadahosi:🔽“kiṁ nu kho so yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhisamecca anumodi udāhu no;🔽yannūnāhaṁ taṁ yakkhaṁ jāneyyaṁ—🔽yadi vā so yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhisamecca anumodi yadi vā no”ti?🔽Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa etat ahosi 🔽kim nu kho saḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhisamecca anumodi udāhu no 🔽yat nūna aham tam yakkham jāneyya 🔽yadi vā saḥ yakkhaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhisamecca anumodi yadi vā na uti 🔽atha kho āyasmai mahāmoggallāna useyyathā api nāma balavā purisaḥ samiñjitam vā bāha
translated: To this extent, ruler of gods, a bhikkhu is liberated by the destruction of craving, the one of perfect vision, the one who has shaken off doubt, the one who has attained to sure knowledge, the one who has attained perfect confidence, the one who has come to the conclusion, the one who has crossed over doubt, the one who has no more perplexity, the one who has become a great man, the one who has attained security, the one who has attained the knowledge of right and wrong, the one who is endowed with the knowledge and the vision of things as they are, the one who has attained to the confidence in the Dhamma, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyans, the one who has attained the right way, the one who has attained the truth, the one who has attained the certain way, the one who has attained the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the Dhamma, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan disciple, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the noble state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained the knowledge of the ariyan state, the one who has attained

original: pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde antarahito
analyzed: pasāreyya pasāritam vā bāham samiñjeyya evam eva pubba ārāme migāra mātu pāsāde antarahitaḥ
translated: and he extended his arm and retracted it, so too—from the Eastern Bamboo Park monastery in the Migāramātā’s Peak,

original: devesu tāvatiṁsesu pāturahosi.🔽Tena kho pana samayena sakko devānamindo ekapuṇḍarīke uyyāne dibbehi pañcahi tūriyasatehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
analyzed: devesu tāvatisesu  tena kho pana samayena sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ ekapuṇḍarīke uyyāne dibbehi pañcahi tūriya satehi samappitaḥ samaṅgībhūtaḥ paricāreti
translated: he disappeared and reappeared among the Tāvatiṃsa devas.

original: Addasā kho sakko devānamindo āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam dūratas u āgacchanta
translated: At that time Sakka, lord of the devas, was enjoying himself together with a large group of devas in the Nandana Grove, in the Delightful Grove, in the Veḷuriya Grove, in the Gem Grove, in the Golden Grove, in the Mansion of Delight, in the Great Delight, in the Dhamma Palace, in the Dhamma Hall, in the Dhamma pavilion, in the Dhamma lotus leaf.🔽Sakka saw Venerable Mahāmoggallāna coming in the distance.

original: Disvāna tāni dibbāni pañca tūriyasatāni paṭippaṇāmetvā yenāyasmā mahāmoggallāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: disvāna tāni dibbāni pañca tūriya satāni paṭippaṇāmetvā yena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam etat avoca
translated: Seeing him, he stopped the five hundred celestial musical instruments and went to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna. He said to him,

original: “ehi kho, mārisa moggallāna, svāgataṁ, mārisa moggallāna.
analyzed: ehi kho mārisa moggallāna svāgata mārisa moggallāna
translated: “Come, good sir Moggallāna! Welcome, good sir Moggallāna!

original: Cirassaṁ kho, mārisa moggallāna, imaṁ pariyāyaṁ akāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
analyzed: cirassam kho mārisa moggallāna imam pariyāyam akāsi yat idam idha āgamanāya
translated: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

original: Nisīda, mārisa moggallāna, idamāsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: nisīda mārisa moggallāna idam āsanam paññattanti
translated: Please sit down, good sir Moggallāna. This seat is ready for you.”

original: Nisīdi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paññatte āsane.
analyzed: nisīdi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paññatte āsane
translated: He sat down on the appointed seat.

original: Sakkopi kho devānamindo aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: sakkaḥ api kho devānamindaḥ aññataram nīcam āsanam gahetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Sakka, ruler of the gods, took a low seat, sat to one side,

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnam kho sakkam devānamindam āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ etat avoca
translated: and the venerable Mahā Moggallāna said to him:

original: “yathā kathaṁ pana kho, kosiya, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ abhāsi?
analyzed: yathā katham pana kho kosiya bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttim abhāsi
translated: “Kosiya, how did the Blessed One explain to you in brief emancipation through the destruction of craving?

original: Sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāgino assāma savanāyā”ti.
analyzed: sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāginaḥ assāma savanāya ati
translated: It would be good if we could get a share in that talk too.”

original: “Mayaṁ kho, mārisa moggallāna, bahukiccā bahukaraṇīyā—
analyzed: mayam kho mārisa moggallāna bahu kiccā bahu karaṇīyā
translated: “We are very busy, dear Moggallāna, we have much to do—

original: appeva sakena karaṇīyena, api ca devānaṁyeva tāvatiṁsānaṁ karaṇīyena.
analyzed: sakena karaṇīyena api ca deva anayā iva karaṇīyena
translated: not only with our own affairs, but also with the affairs of the Thirty-Three Gods.

original: Api ca, mārisa moggallāna, sussutaṁyeva hoti suggahitaṁ sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritaṁ, yaṁ no khippameva antaradhāyati.
analyzed: api ca mārisa moggallāna su sutayā iva hoti suggahitam sumanasikatam su upadhārita yam no khippam eva antaradhāyati
translated: Besides, dear Moggallāna, what we have heard, learned, and seen with our minds may quickly disappear from our minds.

original: Bhūtapubbaṁ, mārisa moggallāna, devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
analyzed: bhūta pubba mārisa moggallāna deva asura saṅgāmaḥ samupabyūḷhaḥ ahosi
translated: Once, dear Moggallāna, a battle was about to be fought between the gods and the asuras.

original: Tasmiṁ kho pana, mārisa moggallāna, saṅgāme devā jiniṁsu, asurā parājiniṁsu.
analyzed: tasmin kho pana mārisa moggallāna saṅgāme devāḥ asurāḥ
translated: In that battle the gods were victorious and the asuras were defeated.🔽Having won that battle, I returned and had a palace built called Victory.

original: So kho ahaṁ, mārisa moggallāna, taṁ saṅgāmaṁ abhivijinitvā vijitasaṅgāmo tato paṭinivattitvā vejayantaṁ nāma pāsādaṁ māpesiṁ.🔽Vejayantassa kho, mārisa moggallāna, pāsādassa ekasataṁ niyyūhaṁ.🔽Ekekasmiṁ niyyūhe satta satta kūṭāgārasatāni.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha mārisa moggallāna tam saṅgāmam abhivijinitvā vijita saṅgāmaḥ tatas paṭinivattitvā vejayantam nāma pāsādam māpesi  vejayantassa kho mārisa moggallāna pāsādassa eka satam niyyūha  ekekasmin niyyūhe satta satta kūṭāgāra satāni
translated: Victory has a hundred courts.🔽In each court there are seven hundred towers.

original: Ekamekasmiṁ kūṭāgāre satta satta accharāyo.
analyzed: ekam ekasmin kūṭāgāre satta satta
translated: In each tower there are seven hundred celestial nymphs.

original: Ekamekissā accharāya satta satta paricārikāyo.
analyzed: ekamekissaḥ accharāya satta satta paricārikāyaḥ
translated: Each celestial nymph has seven hundred attendants.

original: Iccheyyāsi no tvaṁ, mārisa moggallāna, vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakaṁ daṭṭhun”ti?
analyzed: iccheyyāsi no tva mārisa moggallāna vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakam daṭṭhunti
translated: Would you like to see the beauty of Victory?”

original: Adhivāsesi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tuṇhībhāvena.
analyzed: adhivāsesi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ tuṇhībhāvena
translated: The venerable Maha Moggallana consented in silence.

original: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo vessavaṇo ca mahārājā āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ purakkhatvā yena vejayanto pāsādo tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
analyzed: atha kho sakkaḥ ca devānamindaḥ vessavaṇaḥ ca mahā rājā āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam purakkhatvā yena vejayantaḥ pāsādaḥ tena upasaṅkamisu
translated: Then Sakka, ruler of gods, and Vessavana, king of the yakkhas, went with the venerable Maha Moggallana to the palace called Victory.

original: Addasaṁsu kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ;
analyzed: addasasu kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyaḥ āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam dūratas uva āgacchanta
translated: The attendants of Sakka, ruler of the gods, saw Ven. Mahā Moggallāna coming in the distance

original: disvā ottappamānā hirīyamānā sakaṁ sakaṁ ovarakaṁ pavisiṁsu.
analyzed: disvā ottappamānā hirīyamānā sakam sakam ovarakam pavisisu
translated: and, out of embarrassment and shame, entered their own individual huts.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma suṇisā sasuraṁ disvā ottappati hirīyati;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api nāma su nisā sa suram disvā ottappati hirīyati
translated: Just as a daughter-in-law, on seeing her father-in-law, is embarrassed and ashamed,

original: evameva sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ disvā ottappamānā hirīyamānā sakaṁ sakaṁ ovarakaṁ pavisiṁsu.
analyzed: evam eva sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyaḥ āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam disvā ottappamānāḥ hirīyamānā sakam sakam ovarakam pavisisu
translated: in the same way, the attendants of Sakka, ruler of the gods, on seeing Ven. Mahā Moggallāna, were embarrassed and ashamed and entered their own individual huts.

original: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo vessavaṇo ca mahārājā āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ vejayante pāsāde anucaṅkamāpenti anuvicarāpenti:
analyzed: atha kho sakkaḥ ca devānamindaḥ vessavaṇaḥ ca mahā rājā āyasmantam mahāmoggallānam vejayante pāsāde anucaṅkamāpenti anuvicarāpenti
translated: Then Sakka, ruler of the gods, and Vessavaṇa, the great king, led Ven. Mahā Moggallāna to the Vejayanta Palace and showed him around, saying,

original: “idampi, mārisa moggallāna, passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakaṁ;
analyzed: idam pi mārisa moggallāna passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyaka
translated: “See, good sir Moggallāna, how beautiful the Vejayanta Palace is!

original: idampi, mārisa moggallāna, passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakan”ti.
analyzed: idam pi mārisa moggallāna passa vejayantassa pāsādassa rāmaṇeyyakanti
translated: See, good sir Moggallāna, how beautiful the Vejayanta Palace is!”

original: “Sobhati idaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa, yathā taṁ pubbe katapuññassa.
analyzed: sobhati idam āyasmataḥ kosiyassa yathā tam pubbe kata puññassa
translated: “This is beautiful for the venerable one, Kosiya, as it was made by one of good deeds in the past.

original: Manussāpi kiñcideva rāmaṇeyyakaṁ disvā evamāhaṁsu:
analyzed: manussā api kiñcid eva rāmaṇeyyakam disvā evam āhasu
translated: And people, seeing something delightful, said:

original: ‘sobhati vata bho yathā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānan’ti.
analyzed: sobhati vata bho yathā devānam tau atisānanti
translated: ‘How beautiful it is, just like the Thirty-Three Gods’ pleasure park.’

original: Tayidaṁ āyasmato kosiyassa sobhati, yathā taṁ pubbe katapuññassā”ti.
analyzed: tayidam āyasmataḥ kosiyassa sobhati yathā tam pubbe kata puññassa ati
translated: And so it is, venerable sir, that this pleasure park of the venerable Kosiya is beautiful, just as it was made beautiful in the past by his merit.”

original: Atha kho āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa etat ahosi
translated: Then the venerable Maha Moggallana thought:

original: “atibāḷhaṁ kho ayaṁ yakkho pamatto viharati.
analyzed: ati bāḷham kho ayam yakkhaḥ pamattaḥ viharati
translated: “This spirit is living too carelessly.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ yakkhaṁ saṁvejeyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham imam yakkham savejeyyanti
translated: Suppose I were to stir up a sense of urgency in him.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tathārūpaṁ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṁ abhisaṅkhāsi yathā vejayantaṁ pāsādaṁ pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampesi sampakampesi sampavedhesi.
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ tathārūpam iddha abhisaṅkhāram abhisaṅkhāsi yathā vejayantam pāsādam pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampesi sampakampesi sampavedhesi
translated: Then the venerable Maha Moggallana performed such a feat of supernormal power that he made the Vejayanta Palace quake and tremble and shake.

original: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo, vessavaṇo ca mahārājā, devā ca tāvatiṁsā acchariyabbhutacittajātā ahesuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho sakkaḥ ca devānamindaḥ vessavaṇaḥ ca mahā rājā devā ca tāvatisāḥ acchariya bbhuta citta jātāḥ ahesu
translated: Then Sakka, ruler of gods, Vessavana, king of the yakkhas, and the Thirty-Three Gods were amazed and thrilled:

original: “acchariyaṁ vata, bho, abbhutaṁ vata, bho.
analyzed: acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho
translated: “It is wonderful, sirs, it is marvellous

original: Samaṇassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāma dibbabhavanaṁ pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampessati sampakampessati sampavedhessatī”ti.
analyzed: samaṇassa mahiddhika tā mahā anubhāva tā yatra hi nāma dibba bhavanam pādaṅguṭṭhakena saṅkampessati sampakampessati sampavedhessati iti
translated: The great power and might of the ascetic Gotama, in that he can make the deva-world shake with his big toe!’

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ saṁviggaṁ lomahaṭṭhajātaṁ viditvā sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ sakkam devānamindam sa viggam loma haṭṭha jātam viditvā sakkam devānamindam etat avoca
translated: Then, knowing that Sakka had been made anxious and his hair had stood on end, the venerable Maha Moggallana said to him:

original: “yathā kathaṁ pana kho, kosiya, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ abhāsi?
analyzed: yathā katham pana kho kosiya bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttim abhāsi
translated: “But, Kosiya, how did the Blessed Lord briefly expound emancipation through the destruction of craving?

original: Sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāgino assāma savanāyā”ti.
analyzed: sādhu mayampi etissā kathāya bhāginaḥ assāma savanāya ati
translated: It would be good if we could share in that talk.”

original: “Idhāhaṁ, mārisa moggallāna, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ
analyzed: idha āha mārisa moggallāna yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavanta
translated: “Well, sir, I went to the Blessed Lord and,

original: abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho ahaṁ, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavantaṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi ekamantam ṭhitaḥ kho aha mārisa moggallāna bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: after paying homage to him, stood at one side. And I said:

original: ‘kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti
translated: ‘In what way, Lord, is a monk liberated by the destruction of craving, supreme, best, noble, leading the holy life, best of men, an embrasure of heaven?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavā maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte mārisa moggallāna bhagavā mam etat avoca
translated: When I had said this, Lord, the Lord said to me:

original: ‘idha, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti:
analyzed: idha devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: ‘Here, Lord of the Gods, a monk has heard:

original: “sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā”ti.
analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: “All things are unworthy of attachment.”

original: Evañcetaṁ, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti
analyzed: evam ca ita devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: And so he has heard:

original: “sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā”ti.🔽So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā.
analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati  so sabbam dhammam abhijānāti sabbam dhammam abhiññāya sabbam dhammam parijānāti sabbam dhammam pariññāya yam kiñci vedanam vedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā
translated: “All things are unworthy of attachment.”🔽He knows all things, having known all things he fully understands all things, having fully understood all things whatever feeling he feels - whether it is pleasant, painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant - he continues to meditate with himself in equanimity, mindful and aware.

original: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
analyzed: saḥ tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharati virāga anupassī viharati nirodha anupassī viharati paṭinissagga anupassī viharati
translated: He lives contemplating impermanence in all things, contemplating distaste, contemplating abandonment, contemplating destruction.

original: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto, paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,
analyzed: so tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharantaḥ virāga anupassī viharantaḥ nirodha anupassī viharantaḥ paṭinissagga anupassī viharantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: As he lives observing the impermanence of those feelings, observing their fading away and cessation, observing letting go of them, he neither grasps nor delights in anything in the world.

original: anupādiyaṁ na paritassati, aparitassaṁ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:
analyzed: anupādiyam na paritassati a paritassam paccattaññā iva parinibbāyati
translated: Not grasping or delighting, he is not agitated. Not being agitated, he personally attains nibbāna.

original: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He discerns that ‘Birth is ended, the holy life fulfilled, the task done. There is nothing further for this world.’”

original: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho devānaminda bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti
translated: It is in this way, ruler of gods, that a bhikkhu is liberated by the destruction of craving, the one of complete understanding, the supreme person, the foremost person, the one who has attained to the highest attainments, the arahant, the supreme teacher’s disciple.”

original: Evaṁ kho me, mārisa moggallāna, bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ abhāsī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho me mārisa moggallāna bhagavā saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttim abhāsi iti
translated: “That, good sir Moggallāna, is how the Blessed One explained to me the destruction of craving in brief.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sakkassa devānamindassa bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā—seyyathāpi
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ sakkassa devānamindassa bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā aseyyathā api
translated: Then the venerable Mahā Moggallāna delighted and rejoiced in the words of Sakka, ruler of gods. Then he exhorted, instructed, inspired, and gladdened Sakka, ruler of gods, with a Dhamma talk.

original: nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya;🔽evameva—devesu tāvatiṁsesu antarahito pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde pāturahosi.
analyzed: nāma balavā purisaḥ samiñjitam vā bāham pasāreyya pasāritam vā bāham samiñjeyya  evam eva devesu tāvatisesu antarahitaḥ pubbārāme migāra mātupāsāde pāturahosi
translated: Just as a strong man might extend his flexed arm or flex his extended arm,🔽so too did Moggallāna disappear from among the gods of the Thirty-three and reappear in the Eastern Bamboo Park.

original: Atha kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyo acirapakkante āyasmante mahāmoggallāne sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: atha kho sakkassa devānamindassa paricārikāyaḥ acira pakkante āyasmante mahāmoggallāne sakkam devānamindam etat avocuḥ
translated: Soon after he had left, Sakka’s attendants said to him,

original: “eso nu te, mārisa, so bhagavā satthā”ti?
analyzed: esaḥ nu te mārisa saḥ bhagavā satthā ati
translated: “Sir, is that your teacher, the Buddha?”

original: “Na kho me, mārisa, so bhagavā satthā.
analyzed: na kho me mārisa saḥ bhagavā satthā
translated: “No, that’s not my teacher, the Buddha.

original: Sabrahmacārī me eso āyasmā mahāmoggallāno”ti.
analyzed: sabrahmacārī me
translated: That’s my fellow monk, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna.”

original: “Lābhā te, mārisa, suladdhaṁ te, mārisa
analyzed: lābhā te mārisa su laddham te mārisa
translated: “You’re so fortunate, sir, so very fortunate,

original: yassa te sabrahmacārī evaṁmahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo.
analyzed: yassa te sabrahmacārī eva mahiddhikaḥ eva mahā anubhāvaḥ
translated: to have such a powerful and mighty fellow monk.

original: Aho nūna te so bhagavā satthā”ti.
analyzed: aho nūna te saḥ bhagavā satthā ati
translated: Oh, how great must your teacher be!”

original: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavanta
translated: Moggallāna then went to the Buddha, bowed,

original: abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and sat down to one side. Mahāmoggallāna said to the Buddha,

original: “abhijānāti no, bhante, bhagavā ahu ñātaññatarassa mahesakkhassa yakkhassa saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ bhāsitā”ti?
analyzed: abhijānāti no bhante bhagavā ahu ñātaññatarassa mahesakkhassa yakkhassa saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttim bhāsitā ati
translated: “Sir, do you recall ever teaching the complete destruction of craving in brief to a certain very well-known and powerful spirit?”

original: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, moggallāna, idha sakko devānamindo yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā🔽maṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho, moggallāna, sakko devānamindo maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: abhijānāmaha moggallānaḥ idha sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ yena aham tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā  mam abhivādetvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi ekamantam ṭhitaḥ kho moggallāna sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: “I recall doing so, Moggallāna. Once Sakka, lord of the gods, came to me and said,

original: ‘kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bhante bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti
translated: ‘Sir, how is a monk completely free from the underlying tendencies, one who has destroyed the fetters of rebirth, reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary, the ultimate spiritual life, and is foremost among gods and humans?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, moggallāna, sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavocaṁ
analyzed: evam vutte aha moggallāna sakkam devānamindam etat avoca
translated: When he said this, I said to him,

original: ‘idha devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti
analyzed: idha devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti
translated: ‘Here, lord of the gods, a monk has heard

original: “sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā”ti.
analyzed: sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati
translated: ‘All things are unworthy of confidence.’

original: Evaṁ cetaṁ, devānaminda, bhikkhuno sutaṁ hoti🔽“sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā”ti.🔽So sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ abhiññāya sabbaṁ dhammaṁ parijānāti, sabbaṁ dhammaṁ pariññāya yaṁ kiñci vedanaṁ vedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā.🔽So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
analyzed: evam ceta devānaminda bhikkhuno sutam hoti  sabbe dhammā na alam abhinivesāya ati  so sabbam dhammam abhijānāti sabbam dhammam abhiññāya sabbam dhammam parijānāti sabbam dhammam pariññāya yam kiñci vedanam vedeti sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā  saḥ tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharati virāga anupassī viharati nirodha anupassī viharati paṭinissagga anupassī viharati
translated: If a bhikkhu has heard this…

original: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto, virāgānupassī viharanto, nirodhānupassī viharanto,
analyzed: saḥ tāsu vedanāsu anicca anupassī viharantaḥ virāga anupassī viharantaḥ nirodha anupassī viharantaḥ
translated: he understands all things. Having understood all things, he fully understands all things. Whatever feelings he feels, whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant, he abides contemplating impermanence in those feelings, contemplating fading away in those feelings, contemplating cessation in those feelings, contemplating relinquishment in those feelings.

original: paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,
analyzed: paṭinissagga anupassī viharantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati
translated: Contemplating thus, he does not cling to anything in the world.🔽When he does not cling, he is not agitated.

original: anupādiyaṁ na paritassati, aparitassaṁ paccattaññeva parinibbāyati:
analyzed: anupādiyam na paritassati a paritassam paccattaññā iva parinibbāyati
translated: When he does not cling, he is not agitated. When he is not agitated, he personally attains Nibbana.

original: “khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’🔽It is in this way, Lord of the Gods, that a bhikkhu is liberated by the destruction of craving, the one of complete liberation, the supreme, the unsurpassed, the leader of those who follow the spiritual life, the supreme among gods and humans.”🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’

original: Ettāvatā kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan’ti.🔽Evaṁ kho ahaṁ, moggallāna, abhijānāmi sakkassa devānamindassa saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttiṁ bhāsitā”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho devānaminda bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttaḥ hoti accanta niṭṭhaḥ accanta yogakkhemī accanta brahmacārī accanta pariyosānaḥ seṭṭhaḥ deva manussānam ti  evam kho aha moggallāna abhijānāmi sakkassa devānamindassa saṅkhittena taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttim bhāsitā ati
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’🔽“So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete destruction of hatred, the complete destruction of delusion: this is the end of stress.’

original: Attamano āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.🔽Cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhayasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ sattamaṁ.
analyzed: āyasmā mahāmoggallānaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti 🔽cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhaya suttam niṭṭhitam sattama
translated: “So it was with reference to this that it was said: ‘The complete destruction of lust, the complete
